body: @diego-pm Can you limit `protobuf` to `< 4.0.0` or set `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`?
Same for mlflow version 1.11.0. I have set the protobuf to 3.2.0 and works. But I think that mlflow should have all its requirements freezed to and specific version.

> @diego-pm Can you limit `protobuf` to `< 4.0.0` or set `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`?

With protobuf==3.20.1 it works fine. I guess a quick solution would be to set the requirement of protobuf to <4.0.0 in the `setup.py` file.
Can we reopen this issue for an actual fix like pinning the requirement in `setup.py` to `<4.0.0`?
@buhrrr We updated proto code. MLflow 1.26.1 should work with `protobuf>=3.12`.

Given that `mlflow==1.26.1` isnt released yet, how do I fix this for the `mlflow sagemaker build-and-push-container` command? It appears to just install the latest protobuf under the hood while constructing the container which means it doesn't use my system protobuf

> @buhrrr We updated proto code. MLflow 1.26.1 should work with `protobuf>=3.12`.

I tend to agree with @buhrrr this will break again if/when protobuf decides to publish a breaking change. In general it's not a good idea to depends on "any future version of an external library". Why not change it to `protobuf~=3.12` ?

> I tend to agree with @buhrrr this will break again if/when protobuf decides to publish a breaking change.

The same thing can happen for any python package that MLflow depends on. For example, pandas might add a breaking change in the next version. We could pin MLflow's dependencies, but it would make mlflow installation difficult to succeed due to requirement collisions (e.g. `mlflow` requires `protobuf~=3.12` but `tensorflow` requires `protobuf>=4.0.0`).

> The same thing can happen for any python package that MLflow depends on.

Sure, but you can still operate on a per package basis and assume packages aren't adding breaking changes all the time. When they do then lock down conflicting versions so you aren't forcing end users to figure it out for themselves when it's a known issue with a known fix.

> The same thing can happen for any python package that MLflow depends on. For example, pandas might add a breaking change in the next version. We could pin MLflow's dependencies, but it would make mlflow installation difficult to succeed due to requirement collisions (e.g. `mlflow` requires `protobuf~=3.12` but `tensorflow` requires `protobuf>=4.0.0`).

Well yeah and that's a problem, basically any version before the latest is basically broken, it can work but requires investigation from the user. Limiting to the next major release of dependencies seems like a no brainer.

In practice now that the update is done for protobuf 4 it should be something like `protobuf >=3.12, <5.0`.
